BdUIc4RGDtXVZQNTc4EQtw.text: I don't eat southern food often but here on a business trip, I decided to get a taste of the local cuisine.  I had the calabash flounder which is served with cole slaw and fries.  I had sides of collard greens and potato salad with it when I misunderstood a mumbling waiter that sides were al a carte.  The collard greens were excellent!  The potato salad was a bust.  The calabash fish, fries and slaw were good but not extraordinary.  BTW, the mumbling waiter was a nice guy and the misunderstanding was as much a result of my old ears as his mumbling.  I'd eat here again.

uZKUQgdRAS9yVZMRJO2kfw.text: I was wondering around E.Trade St. looking for something to eat, and I came across this restaurant. The fact that it is located at the intersection and the restaurant looks semi-classy with a nice outdoor patio attracted me. I ordered their famous fried chicken (a recommendation from a lot of people from Yelp, and the waitress) and Stella for beer. Honestly, I was not too impressed. The fried-chicken tasted dry (not juicy enough for me). Maybe because I live right across the border from Kentucky, but Kentucky does have the best fried chicken in the world. This review is based on their famous fried chicken, but I would like to go back and try other stuff on their menu, their entree list looked pretty but a little pricey...more reviews to come!

j2akczekfOzylN3_forXaQ.text: Our waiter Stuart was the greatest! Side dishes are the show!! Fried chicken and short ribs were very good. Try the banana pudding for dessert.

5ZIMfe_p24kuX_COkcNo3g.text: I've wanted to visit this restaurant for months now. My gf and I went here the other night and, unfortunately, it was a disappointment.   We walked in on Fri night and stood right next to the hostess for a good minute. She knew we were there, nothing was said to us, and she just kept talking to the waiter. Now, one minute is much longer than it sounds when you walk in and expect to be greeted by someone. Bad taste in our mouths immediately. Not major, just something we both thought was strange.   We got a nice table, good place to hear the live jazz (we're both Jazz lovers!). The waiter informed us that they were out of the pot roast. No biggie. She ordered the Salmon; I ordered the fried chicken meat & three. I ordered Mac-n-Cheese, fried cabbage, and mashed potatoes & gravy.  5 minutes later, the waiter informed us that they were out of Salmon. Small to medium biggie. She ordered something else and we drank some wine.   A solid 40 minutes later, our food comes out. Major biggie.   Hers looks great. Out of the three sides I ordered, two were wrong. Mac-n-cheese was there, but I got collard greens instead of cabbage and black eyed peas instead of mashed potatoes. Large biggie.   I'm the LAST person to complain in my family and, even when I do, I am the most polite complainer anywhere around. Just get the order right, that's all. Overall, the food was great. That's why I am annoyed - because the food was great and the service wasn't. It's a shame to have great food and several things happen along the way that makes the customer not want to return which, sadly, may be the case with us. Along with the food mistakes, etc., our waiter was completely frantic the entire night. Just didn't give us a good vibe in there.   Looks like there's some work to do for this kitchen.

Lqpr8EgYzmgsRLzE7zKL2A.text: This is easily one of my favorite spots in Charlotte. The food here is out of this world and very reasonably priced. True southern style cuisine that is clearly made with love.  I usually get the fried chicken which is INSANE. The collard greens and Mac and cheese will change your life. My wife like the porterhouse porkchop which literally melts in your mouth.   And being a music minister in a local church, the mission of this place is incredible. Look them up and read about their history. You will not be disappointed.

-Yb7GUipgJPbYMlzm-iK0Q.text: I was excited to try King's after all the great reviews but come on people, this was garbage. We ordered our food and it came in 4 minutes, really? The chicken had been cooked ahead of time, not crispy, soggy on bottom from sitting around. You get your choice of sides if they didn't runout of it. I had the green beans, they should  have told me they were from a can, so disgusting. The mac & cheese was lumpy and not hot. The slaw was ok. The waiter didn't know what beers they had, he went and asked. He poured my beer in a glass until the foam was overflowing onto the table. This restaurant is a joke! If you like buffet style taste and quality then this is the place for you!

O89gU2bU_UI_qem_V40zuQ.text: The shrimp and grits were so yummy.  Smooth and spicy grits.  Sorry forgot to snap a pic. Everyone else loved their food too.  Fried flounder so tender! Tri tip excellent, mahi light and tender.   Excellent service.

Yd67oRTpymSXYdzbNUJ-CA.text: The food was great - classic, Southern, meat plus three and creole shrimp and grits, fried catfish the size of my head - and great value.   The service was what ruined it.   Slow, nonexistent at times, with multiple servers running around confusing us.  When I asked to see the dessert menu (great desserts, too, pecan pie made of pecans and not corn syrup!) I was presented the lunch menu, without the explanation that the prices were up to $3 cheaper than the dinner menu prices (which was what I was charged, of course).   Overall, just inadequate service, especially in light of how many busybodies there were running around and IGNORING us as we sat in the middle of the room trying to draw someone, ANYONE's attention to order.   Again, great food, great price.. and so I might try it again, but maybe I can get a buzzer or a card or something to hold up so my server can claim me.

r9s4CdqmZO3y3xtwX6OtAw.text: My entire family and I went to The King's Kitchen in May to celebrate my finishing grad school.  I made a reservation for 8 about a week prior to the Saturday night dinner.  When we arrived at the restaurant, we were pleasantly surprised to find that we had a private room reserved.  Although fancier than the traditional "meat and three," it is still just that, so dont go expecting something very gourmet.  Likes:  Pleasant atmosphere, attentive waiter who obviously takes a lot of pride in his job, the food was all great (the appetizers, meat, and the sides were all delicious).  Dislikes:  Parking.  We parked in a garage and walked.  And then it rained on our heads.  But I guess that's what happens in downtown Charlotte.  Take it or leave it:  Take it.  Fun place with good food for an good cause.  I'm willing to support anyone who has a different business model than the traditional restaurant.

sq1cwZb1RaoytV-_aUvp1w.text: Definitely the best fried chicken i've ever had, ever, by far.  The wait staff was great.  The restaurant has an upscale vibe, but not pretentious.  Just a great atmosphere and solid food.

OIuiRT2tP_CPeH7eAQXRjg.text: Really enjoyed my dinner here. Great cheese plate. The creamed corn might have been my favorite side although all were delicious. The brisket was really nice, a tad salty. Wish I tried the desserts, I'll definitely be back!

7PJHcvcLzV_uLKEENVyvpQ.text: Had the gumbo and the po boy. Initially, we sat outside, but moved inside due to the loud traffic. Overall, great food, and a great waiter as well (Stewart). And most importantly, the overall goal of the restaurant is awesome!

UMj6QhuDh8na5GlHpTgYXw.text: We don't get to eat uptown too often since we work near the airport.  However, we made a special trip to the King's Kitchen today with a group of 10 people (we made reservations).  You probably know that The King's Kitchen is a non-profit restaurant owned by Charlotte chef and minister Jim Noble.  The restaurant began with no debt; it was all paid for which helps them give more back to people.  In a place serving mostly southern style food, I had to get sweet tea, which is not one of my faves.  However, if all sweet tea tasted like this, I'd probably drink it much more often.  We ordered some pimento cheese for an app, which was a decent size scoop but served with only about 5 crackers.  This wasn't a problem when the made-from-scratch biscuits and cornbread came out though.  They tasted great by themselves, but they were also good with the cheese.  I make pimento cheese often, and prefer mine with more of a kick of hot sauce, but this cheese was still very good.  I got the pan-fried all natural chicken with white meat.  The chicken was slightly dry (because white meat often is) but the breading made up for it.  It tasted like they used panko and that stuff is awesome.  The meat comes with three sides for lunch, so I got mac and cheese, mashed sweet potatoes, and fruit.  The sweet potatoes were awesome and so was the mac and cheese.  Everyone ordered a variety of items and everyone really liked what they got (keep in mind more than half of this group are native southerners and two are even native to Charlotte).  The pineapple upside down cake was also moist sweet, and delicious.    It took a little bit to get our checks, but that's a minor issue.  It's a rare occurrence when a restaurant gets our group's order 100% correct and even rarer when everyone loves their food.

dpARHWEgezjWF7QMU9Wt6w.text: Anyone who says it's tough to screw up fried chicken obviously hasn't made much of it....or eaten any "bad" fried chicken. Thank goodness the fine folks at King's Kitchen have that dish down pat!   I have been waiting to head over to this nonprofit phenom for quite some time and finally got a chance to grab some dinner here. I'll put it out there right now - I love the concept of a nonprofit restaurant. I love the idea of feeding those who are without and putting people to work who are in transition. Now that that's clear, let's focus on the food & experience.   The restaurant hosts clean lines, bright walls and nice lighting. Hubs and I chose to sit out on the patio and enjoy a late dinner. Our waiter, Stuart, was incredibly friendly and led us through the menu with ease. A few glasses of wine later, we were ready to order. As mentioned, I chose the fried chicken with roasted carrots and mac & cheese. The bird was perfectly crispy and super juicy - honestly, it rivals my grandmother's fried chicken and that's say a whole lot. The carrots had the perfect amount of sweetness and were by no means overcooked. And lastly, the mac and cheese was heart attack worthy and delightful. Price wise, I think $13 was a completely fair (and affordable) price for this plate of food. The portions aren't gargantuan, but they are plenty large for the price!   We finished off the evening with strawberry shortcake - made with biscuits, fresh strawberries and whipped cream. While the treat was refreshing and tasty, the biscuits were a bit stiff and the portion was on the smaller side. Thus, I need to come back and try the coconut chess or chocolate pie. Oh woe is me.   I'm looking forward to coming back for another royal dinner at King's Kitchen...if I were to grab lunch here I may fall into an afternoon food coma!

UXoi4NWKD6t1y3aZkvAKog.text: This is simply a wonderful restaurant with fresh real food.  I found it here on yelp when I was in town for two days.  I went with a lovely lady friend and we had simply a wonderful evening.  Food, atmosphere, and my company could not of been better.    We both had the fried chicken which was excellent.

w11CoE__CVpKIsJzr8F54A.text: I would have given it five stars other than for the fact that I got sick that night. It could have been from my fried oyster salad.   Other than that *possible* mishap, I thought this place was dynamite. I will come back next time I'm in Charlotte.

Vt0ADfEz94idXEGx6sfOUg.text: The food felt like home. We went on a random Monday night. We started with the fried oysters with bacon vinaigrette and cocktail sauce. Succulent and a bit spicy. My had the spare ribs and he said they were great and enough that he had to take some home. I had the fried catfish with okra, tomatoes and andouille sausage. I don't eat sausage, but the catfish was very nicely breaded and fried. I could have stood a bit more seasoning. The carmel cake was also to die for.   Our server (don't think he ever gave his name) was nice, but perhaps a bit too "busy" as it was hard to flag him over sometimes. Also, I waited 10 mins before being seated - no one asked me if I was meeting someone or if I needed to be seated... But, overall, good place.

1IgrHB8CBnbcYoduDd3zNg.text: In my restaurant rating system, this is a level 3 restaurant (out of 5) .  I only measure food and service.  I give the food a weight of 2/3rd and service by 1/3.   For level 3 place The food was good.  I ordered the fried chicken - hot & moist.   I like mine with more spices.  Potatoes and gravy -  tasted home-made.  Butter beans - nice.  Beets- a little wrinkled / over cooked but still good and worth ordering. Food came out a little to fast indicating most is sitting on a warmer though don't know if this is True.     Service was attentive.   I'd come here again.  Solid predictable.

90iAOSeQyDGRHGrxOCuMYg.text: My boyfriend and I have been wanting to eat at The King's Kitchen now for awhile. We felt like some comfort food while uptown and this did the trick! They start the meal off with perfect biscuits as well as some super moist corn bread. Very good. We also split the deviled eggs (not at all runny) and the fried polenta. It almost tasted like fried cheese! Then, my boyfriend ordered the blackened catfish with the mac and cheese, greens and stewed tomatoes and I got the fried chicken with carrots, mac and cheese and green beans. We got all of that for $40. The service was pretty good. We thought our server may have forgotten about bringing us the bread, but she brought it after we ate the eggs and polenta which was actually better.

7k_4d73n4TcpBCQjK-WuAg.text: Comfort food....If I had a last meal request, rest assured it would be comfort/soul food and it may very well come from King's Kitchen.  I've only dined here three times but each time has been phenomenal.  My favorite...side dish.....is the cornbread.  I hope my mom doesn't read this but it's the best cornbread I've ever tasted!  Service is always great and all the proceeds go to a good cause so that warms my heart while the food warms my belly....perfect combo :)  Be a king....eat here!

a-wolqN74L-TwHqRFckjXA.text: Admittedly we've only sampled a few restaurants in the Queen City, but this was our favorite. The atmosphere was casual, yet chic, the food was fresh and delicious (though a bit over salted), and our waiter, Danielo was attentive and delightful. And all for such a worthy cause. We will return.

aRIWgJo4dBMzrpDklebD8Q.text: It wasn't until last night that I realized that I dislike when multiple sides are served in lots of little bowls. Sure if something is soupy that makes sense for the integrity of the dish. Kings Kitchen serves your heaping of sides on a gigantic plate with your main (for the most part).   This is food like if your momma could cook. Service was attentive without being overbearing. We felt taken care of and also had time to have a long conversation.   We both had the dark meat fried chicken that comes with three sides for $13. A very generous portion.   The mashed potatoes were dynamite and I'm not a gravy fan, these worked. The green beans are cooked with pork, they are smokey and savory. Creamed corn was sweet and did the job.   Nice to see glasses of wine for $7 and $8 on the menu.   My first world gripe? No valet parking on a recent week night. Tons of lots and decks spitting distance away through.

R7aJCqvuwkb9sJVIlDqLIw.text: Came here for dinner when my family was in town and it was a hit! I absolutely love the mission of this restaurant and I think it's so important to have businesses here that focus on the needs of our city.  King's Kitchen has a mission to help the homeless in uptown charlotte not just by providing meals, but through a rehabilitation program that helps homeless individuals learn life skills, stay on track and find work. Most of their staff is part of the program.  Not only is this a restaurant with a great cause behind it, the food is delicious also! The owner of King's Kitchen also owns Rooster's, so I'm not surprised that the food is top notch. They have a variety of classic Meat and Three options with fresh ingredients and home cooked flavor.   My only gripe is that they ran out of fried chicken before 7:30! That was the main thing I wanted to try. I asked them to substitute the fried fish instead and it was till fantastic so I guess I can't be too upset!

d0r2BGdtjJC-eSP2AaQB_A.text: I meant to give two stars for the ambiance and service.  Based on the many positive Yelp reviews and the socially conscience message of the restaurant to provide for those that are less fortunate, a friend and I dined at King's Kitchen.  We arrived at 5:00 pm, the restaurant was practically empty with only three patrons which to me meant we would have the best service.  Outdoor dining is provided and absolutely I love dining al fresco, so we ate on the covered patio.  The restaurant is lovely with lots of windows so the natural light just flows in, the decor is simple and rustic but very inviting, the windows feature transparent recipes that is eye-catching and clever but that is where the compliments end.  I looked online at the menu and photo gallery to get an idea of what was offered.  The menu had several options that I liked and the photo gallery featured delicious looking food that I could not wait to try.  While the service was okay, the food was horrible.  I ordered sweet tea and thought I was going to get a sugar high.  It was entirely too sweet, someone must have put in a bag of sugar.  I asked for a glass of ice to temper the sweetness which helped.  We ordered biscuits which were heavy, thick and dry but for the accompaniments of butter, honey and jam, followed by long swallows of our beverage the biscuits would not have been eaten.  The biscuits were described by the server as light and fluffy, they weren't.    I was torn between the salmon, catfish and fried chicken as an entree but ultimately decided on fried chicken - white meat with two orders of macaroni and cheese, green beans and cornbread.  The macaroni and cheese was the worst I've ever had, it was runny as if it wasn't completely baked, the pasta was al-dente; it should have been allowed to cook longer.  I traded plates with my friend because the macaroni and cheese was so fluid that it spread, it began to touch my chicken and corn bread.  My friend also ordered macaroni and cheese as a side but his was in a small bowl, so I took that but it was the same only compact so that it was not fluid.  I sent the macaroni and cheese back for mash potatoes and gravy.  It was worse than the macaroni and cheese.  The potatoes which I believe were Yukon gold were either waterlogged from sitting in water or cooked too long and absorbed too much water because they looked gummy and had a sticky texture, and the gravy was bland with a heavy taste of flour.  The cornbread was heavy, incredibly dry and bland even after putting butter on it.  I ate the chicken and green beans.  Although the chicken was fine, it needed to be moist and I found myself using the flour tasting gravy to dip the chicken.  My friend ate about three forkfuls of the macaroni and cheese before he gave up on it.  He had the catfish and said it was bland but he could tolerate it.  He also had the potato salad what was not good and did not bother to finish it.  The online photo gallery showed amazing desserts, so we both ordered coconut cake.  When it was served, it looked beautiful with tall stacked mini-cakes, coconut icing and a drizzle of something.  However, at first bite it was incredibly cold, as if it was stored in the freezer, taken out to defrost and topped with fresh icing and drizzle of something.  I love coconut and would have devoured that cake but it was disgusting.  I asked for it to be removed from the bill.  My friend said his was too cold but would take it home to eat at room temperature, he threw it away.  What a waste of $10.00 for something that he did not eat because of the taste.  I cannot cook well and enjoy eating out but when the meal is horrible like this, I have become more patient at learning to cook at home whether than waste time and money at a restaurant with subpar food.  We did speak to the manager about our experience, he removed the charge of my dessert and I thought he said he credited my meal but he didn't.  Instead of addressing the matter, we just paid and left, never to return again.  I also learned from the server, that Rooster's Wood-fire Kitchen is its sister restaurant.  Rooster also has a lot of good reviews and was on my list of restaurants to try.  However, out of fear that the food will be subpar as with King's Kitchen, I will stay away from Rooster's.

eQa_vLCK9QVcRaB4iGAvhw.text: We really enjoyed our dinner here and are fully behind its mission. They help get those who are having trouble making ends meet get back on their feet by hiring and/or feeding them. We had the crab cake and pimento cheese plate as appetizers- both were fabulous. Two of us got vegetable plates. The Mac and cheese, corn, and green beans were our favorites. The cornbread is also great. The shrimp and grits was spicy and tasty. We finished with the coconut cake-yum. Great place!!

mZ4A_6Lwk85tJEVzjIYb_Q.text: Stayed at the Marriott across the street and wanted something close by and wasn't into Hooter's.  Definitely glad we ate at The King's Kitchen!  Incredible southern food.  I ordered the Pot Roast and a large piece of meat came that I pushed apart easily with my fork.  It was cooked perfectly and it came with three sides.  The creamed corn was amazing.  My colleagues ordered the shrimp and grits and the ravioli and loved both of them.  The service was a little slow but they were busy with everyone from the tradeshow staying at the Marriott, so I'll let that go.  We didn't know anything about the mission of the business until we noticed the large cross in the kitchen and then started noticing the other subtle things around the restaurant.  They are upfront about their mission but not in your face, which is nice, so they're not going to turn anyone away.  I will definitely be back next time I'm in town!

AcbyF3m2VBIrxkYn6U-hhg.text: Was really interested to come here as I'd heard it uses a similar nonprofit model to Seattle's FareStart Cafe that does homeless outreach. Glad we made a reservation as the place was packed on Saturday at 730pm.   Started with the crab cakes, which were a bit small but delicious. Biscuits & cornbread were nothing to write home about. For mains we had a Red Snapper than came with a creamy sauce and farro that I really liked although the fish was a little bit overcooked. The Shrimp and Grits were the BEST we have had anywhere. The grits were the perfect consistency for soaking up the spicy sauce that came with it. We finished with a bread pudding that was well worth the wait: the bread was super fresh and the custard was among the best we've had.   Service was great, would definitely come back here.

photos.caption: Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States. Bread pudding, dee-lish!

pY5h6dCopKF5JRc41qyQCg.text: Omg... worst restaurant experience of 2017 . The waitress was sooo weird. She was def on drugs.. My shrimp and grits was good but so thin and watery.. I finished it in 10 mins and was still hungry.  My husband got the pot roast. Creamed corn was suspect. Left with a $71.00 bill and we were both still hungry. How did this place get 4 stars? Baffled.

MX0MaOAd_hJRQ6NKN-_pXQ.text: AMAZING!!! Sat down as soon as we walked in, ordered and dinner was out within 10 minutes. By far the best service in charlotte.

JXIKdcjTNqeKpYe_8woGww.text: I like the food and ambience here. The sides which are offered along with the dish you order may have pork in it( ex beans) so you may confirm with them before placing an order.

photos.caption: Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States. Grilled salmon with corn bread, sweet potato mash and creamy sweet corn

6YVpdo2DfYMUgPrGMpYsOg.text: I really enjoyed the food, service was good, my wife really enjoyed it as well, the only reason I gave it a 4was when I initially ordered they were out of two of the items I wanted to try. What I ordered was good, but not what I really wanted.

qBPmmzepT2FuC6fP7VxaMQ.text: We had been traveling all day and happened upon this just as we were getting hangry. Several of the things we wanted were sold out which was quite the disappointment. We probably should have gotten up and left as what we ended up with was good but not why we went there (fried chicken). We sat at the bar and the bartender seemed to be very busy and didn't have much time for us. Interestingly, we would have preferred one of the many empty tables but we were told we couldn't sit there. It is important to note that we were there at 7pm on a Saturday night- not exactly closing time.

WEeGztRmh2FpcBYQwiEOxA.text: I have waited three years to write this review ladies and gentlemen. The King's Kitchen is just a remarkable place all around. From the relativley modern and simple yet solemn interior design to the wonderful group of people who make our visit such a delightful event. The location is also super convenient from all sides of Uptown - for those of you who aren't in Charlotte, that's our downtown.   Today I had the salmon for dinner and it was just great. I love salmon in many different forms and enjoy various sorts of recipes. Unfortunately, as we all know, not all places do it good enough. The King's Kitchen was on point. Not too mushy and not too dry inside covered with seasoned and (most importantly) crispy outer layer for an excellent experience. I cannot end today's review without mentioning the mushrooms. Yes, they were perfect. Last but not least, the lady who brought extra pimento cheese for our baguette, you rock. The manager was super quick and smart too. Keep it up!  There is a unique story behind this place which I will save for all of you readers to go find out for yourselves. You will like it just for that, and love it for the tuna sandwiches, the salmon, and their amazing desserts.

photos.caption: Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States. The King&#39;s supper.
Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States. Pimento cheese, and french baguette.

MVBcacb20AOd5679DYIuSw.text: The Kings Kitchen is a great place to eat while helping out your community and those in need at the same time.  If you have an event coming up give them a call for reasonable catering options, or ask them about hosting the event at their restaurant!  They are a non-profit on a mission to help those dealing with some of life's toughest challenges including poverty, homelessness, substance abuse and incarceration. Drop by for a cup of coffee or classic southern fried chicken sandwich.

vRxNMz3_4KlpStPo8-_drA.text: The service was great, we were seated right away and did not have reservations. Tried the gumbo it was decent but a little thick on the roux. I ordered the pot roast , very tender and tasty. Did not like the cream corn. The greens and cornbread were to my liking. My friend had the fried chicken and enjoyed it. This is decent southern food but definitely not soul food. I'm from Texas where we eat soul food.   We mainly went because we support the causes S the fact that it is a non profit giving back.

Sy68NQoXWjprF8q588ZXiQ.text: I originally would give this restaurant only two stars, but I am bumping it up to three because of their noble intentions and unique concept of southern food with a modern twist.  I arrived with two other friends at about 8:30 on a Wednesday, so the restaurant was almost empty. We were served promptly and our waitress Kristen was very attentive. She served us classic southern sweet tea and was prompt with refills.  We got sweet potato fritters, which had a unique taste, but very enjoyable. Two of us got the fried chicken with three sides and cornbread ($13), which was an awesome deal. The mashed potatoes & gravy and the creamed corn were absolutely delicious. The fried chicken was pretty good, but somewhat dry. The green beans and mac n cheese were also above average, but nothing spectacular. However, the cornbread was terrible. It had clearly been made and cut that morning or prior to; it was dry and stale on the outside and the inside was tasteless.   In general, I had a nice time but I would like to return when it was a little more busy, due to the fact that the restaurant is pretty large and it felt like nobody was there. Also, I would skip the cornbread and perhaps order a dessert, because what we saw in the dessert counter looked delicious.

photos.caption: Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States. Fried chicken with mashed potatoes and gravy, green beans, mac n cheese, and cornbread

SbbW8j1JvhvDWNcCxB4cBA.text: We went for a late lunch and had incredible service! We got the meatloaf and three and the catfish and three. The meat and three options are the best value on the menu! It was absolutely delicious! The best part was the collard greens!

photos.caption: Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States. Meatloaf and 3 and Catfish and 3.

Nizb1QO5UIFMAdwJxzZupg.text: Great service, reasonable prices & even better food. I just ordered the vegetable plate & was very fulfilled. All of the food was seasoned to perfection. I got the mushrooms, mac, mashed potatoes & green beans. Everyone in my party also loved their food, especially the fried chicken. I would definitely recommend this place to others.

zDHellc7ti2OYxVGP6VQhg.text: Amazing beet salad to start, shrimp and grits were fabulous and seasoned perfectly for me. Portions were perfectly sized even though I could eat a lot more. Excellent attentive service. Really glad I chose this restaurant for my visit to Charlotte. The banana pudding comes in a drinking glass with amazing toasted marshmallow fluff on the top. I could have eaten three of those.

VCJTguVG7QL3RKPn3J4kVQ.text: It took me a while to get back here but I did! Now as a resident of Charlotte; I've been making the rounds and we are onto repeats. I had the fried chicken with sides; it has gone downhill. Chicken was dry and creamed corn was too sweet. Pick something else! My Riesling was really good and one of our friends got a great recommendation from our waiter when she picked a wine that had been 86'd. My husband had the flounder with fries and his meal is the reason I'm giving 4 stars again. He loved his dinner! Large portion, not greasy and fresh. We also ordered the cheese plate which was light on cheese for $15. We finished with the coconut cake tower which was cold from the fridge but we attacked it anyways. I would've just liked it room temperature but I know I'm just being picky. Overall, the food was good and the service was kind. Give it a try; King's Kitchen is better than many of the chains in uptown!

90mi3nZD1cYFJgW3FLWtPg.text: Short version is: great food but spotty service.   In town on business and guided by Yelp. I really appreciate the mission. Portions are well sized, prices are reasonable, and food is insanely good.   The drink I ordered never arrive despite asking twice and the butter beans I ordered were replaced by potatoes. Food came out with 10 minutes of order being placed. I am all for fast service but was hoping to enjoy my beer that never arrived first.   Will I go back next time here? Doubtful but it's worth a visit.

Vvdm_dvVxXgDKIzyx2tT4A.text: King's Kitchen has restored a little of my faith in humanity. If there were more places like King's Kitchen, the world would be a better place!   You've heard the rumors, and they're all True. The King's Kitchen is a non-profit restaurant that has good food, good business model, and it benefits the local community. Job training program combines with feeding the hungy. Excellent customer service, and well executed food don't hurt either. All for a reasonable price. And the ambiance is clean and casually upscale. Jeans would fit in and so would suits. Plasma TVs on mute keep is a little casual, as do the servers in jeans.   First, our waiter (who had a very unique name that is escaping me but he was awesome) was informative, friendly, and funny. He explained the mission of the restaurant and made some recommendations that were all excellent.    APPS Deviled eggs were pretty standard but an excellent way to start the meal. Cornbread was phenomenal! I hauled this cornbread back to Washington DC to eat it, it was that good. The biscuits are also stellar, but I'm a cornbread girl.   MAIN COURSE Pan fried chicken. Although I do like the crispiness of deep fried chicken, this pan fried one was well seasoned, moist and tasty. Mac n cheese was a little too creamy, but was devoured before anything else on the plate. Greens were good. My companions heartily enjoyed their oxtail and potroast.  Beer and wine selection was excellent (I got a pint of Fat Tire, and there were some tempting wines on the list too)  DESSERT I don't really like bananas. And I don't really like pudding. But their banana pudding was pretty tasty!  Overall, I had good food and a wonderful time at King's Kitchen without breaking the bank. Now just open a branch in DC!

-Gl-KhfQUJwlncJ9VRYYJA.text: We visited during the CIAA. Service was great and pleasant considering this is one of Charlotte's busiest time. Food is flavorful and good. Menu has something for everyone. Atmosphere is very nice. Definitely will be my go to spot when in Charlotte.

NmelPCvxCTy4LpsimnyrEQ.text: So I came to Charlotte for work, and I stayed in downtown without a car and I really wanted to see what type of food they got around here. Since, I never had True southern food, I wanted to give this place a try. The unique thing about this restaurant is that it's an non profit restaurant. That's right non profit.   The place is really cute, very modern with white walls, open seating, nice decor. The staff here is extremely nice! I got a True southern man as my waiter and he was so caring and made my experience here that much better.   I got the True fried chicken plate, you get two sides and I choose the mac and cheese and corn bread. What can I say? I wanted the whole south experience! The fried chicken was delicious! It was not dry and it was done to perfection! The mac and cheese was good too! The corn bread unfortunately was a little dry. I honestly think the corn bread would have been better if it came out warm or hot.   If I was ever in Charlotte again. I would come here for sure for my True southern experience!

db77dU2tUZLBPRTMdDCEeg.text: Great authentic southern food. Convenient to offices uptown. Good location to take friends/clients if you're looking for authentic southern uptown.

iW7or26i01fMwxT4PCOH4A.text: In Charlotte southern kitchen restaurants are plentiful, including upscale ones. The King's is mid-scale. $27 for lunch for two. I had the meatloaf, black eyed peas, collard greens and butter beans. All yummy. Wish there were places like this in Los Angeles.

i_OJWOPNbXuRWbT2Wk2r8w.text: To start out, if I were to write this review a year ago, it would be much different.  I would have said, "Good food, Good Service and Great Prices and I recommend everyone should try this place at least once".    Unfortunately, as Cara said in a previous review, something has happened to the Kings kitchen over the last year.  I do not know what has happened, but the prices have increased and the portions and food no longer meet the expectations that Kings kitchen once met.    Today I ordered the Grilled Chicken wrap with fries, the other people that were with me got a Grilled Chicken wrap as well and a turkey sandwhich.  The wrap was mostly all lettuce and a 1/2 of a breast of chicken (the other person at the table got the other half).  This was not an $11 wrap.  The Turkey sandwhich had, at most, 3 pieces of Turkey on it, but plenty of lettuce.  All 3 of us got fries and they were greasy and soggy.  The other 2 people like their fries this way, so that is neither a positive or negative to kings kitchen.    I hope kings Kitchen can fix whatever has broke and get back to the way it was.  If this happens, I will be ecstatic to be able to recommend this place again.

eiBdTnsdGFy-_MRtXF9XMQ.text: Am in Charlotte, NC on business and found this place up the road from my hotel.  I thought their mission to help the less fortunate to be a nice reason to stop by, but I so thoroughly enjoyed my meal I would totally recommend it to anyone.  I had the sweet potato fritters to start (AMAZING!) and followed it with the fried chicken tacos which were a special that evening.  The outdoor seating was a nice treat after a long winter too....

31ha-6qfBoIj5BoehO__gw.text: Food was terrible. I had the fried chicken, mashed potatoes, green beans, and Mac and cheese. EVERYTHING was unbearably nasty and definitely so considering how overpriced it was. I got it Togo so idk how dining in would be.

cLgbKGfeBWzmPON40mQzKQ.text: Place stinks. Walked in and they don't even tell you half their food isn't available to order that night.

iSK0a5OPjBCgxhpIuvN8pw.text: Great fresh locally sourced food and fantastic service!! This was my second time here, first time was for lunch and tonight for dinner. You have to try the tomato bisque it's fabulous!

OrsMVhXzMWZTm81Qa1rtuw.text: Not that impressed with the food! Service was average and wait time was a little long.

KaOqFqasTB5isjKtl-TVoQ.text: Great ambiance, nice beer selection, interesting service, slammin' food. Don't leave without trying the biscuits! I tried the Shrimp & Grits, cabbage and Mac & Cheese and want to relive it all. Definitely would recommend to a friend!

fkFqoKHFuDLp1-U9Y47w_g.text: This place opens at 7am but doesn't have food! I got there at 10am, they didn't have 2 of the 4 things on the menu and they messed up my order. Pretty restaurant, poor foid

RHdOHmjri4UzQJxRccytkg.text: Going with a perfect score for my first time there last night with a group of six. The waitress was welcoming and friendly. She took good care of the table without breathing down our necks every few minutes. We had fried oysters for the table, the breading was awesome, I really enjoyed them.  Also, locally crafted beers and ciders, and wines, however they "do not have spirits" so just a heads up. We all got a cup of the gumbo, I've never actually had gumbo before, so I don't know if it's truly authentic, but it was truly delicious!   I had the pan fried chicken, it comes with three sides. The sides and specials are seasonally based, since everything is sourced locally I believe, so they didn't have a few options, but the Mac and cheese, slaw, and green beans, which are cooked with bacon, were good. The chicken was awesome, right amount of breading, very juicy.  Three people in our group got the pot roast and it was a big hit!  The other two got the NY strip, which I think was the special of the night. Both stated it may have been the best steak they ever had.  We found ourselves wanting to return quickly to try the other menu items, so we will be back!

VqF5vaiQUBi2Yu9FZ_75Fw.text: I ate here about a week ago with  some friends from work. I got the chicken salad and it was very yummy. The chicken was very juicy, had a lot of flavor and was seasoned well. I usually don't like chicken salad that much( because of the mayonnaise) but I can definitely see myself eating from here again. And ordering the same thing.

AMcAmUllOz1VNzF7RIRv4g.text: Before I talk about the food, I think it's important to note what this place is.  It is a not for profit restaurant and the proceeds go towards local organizations that help the poor and needy in the community.  Additionally, the restaurant gives jobs to folks who are considered to be "un-employable" due to troubled pasts.  All this is done under the auspices of religion.  Whether or not you are a religious person, the cause is noble and sincere.  And they don't shove it down your throat, they just serve you good food and treat you well while doing it.    So, on to the restaurant itself.  It's in a really cool location on the corner of Trade and Church that you cannot miss.  Lots of windows make it very attractive.  The atmosphere is very casual and comfortable.    When we arrived, we were seated at a table that was awkwardly placed against a wall right under a mammoth flat screen TV.  That part was a little disappointing but no major issue.  Our waitress was kind, attentive, and offered good recommendations.  There were all sorts of delicious looking down-home dishes on the menu.  I went with the fried catfish which was pretty excellent I must say.  It was served up with mushrooms, sweet potato puree, and corn pudding.  The portions were good sized but not enormous, so I didn't leave feeling like I ate half of Charlotte.  There were really tasty looking desserts to pick from (pecan tart, a truffle trio, banana pudding, coconut cake, etc.).  We went with the caramel cake which was accompanied by a dollop of coffee ice cream.  That thing didn't stand a chance!  Cool atmosphere, good food, friendly staff, all backed by a humanitarian cause.

NYfNf00FzqV0F5Y1FrXdCA.text: The food here is good, but is more the concept of the restaurant that keeps me coming back. The prices are a bit high for the quality of food that is served.

v0MvvMEOP_GKH5nHT0jHbg.text: What everyone else said and then some! Given the mission statement of this restaurant and being a sucker for comfort food, I've been wanting to check out this place since I read about it in the Charlotte Observer. I went for lunch yesterday-at 11:40A when we got there, there were maybe 3 tables occupied-when we left at 12:20P, the place was packed with a waiting list. This is in Charlotte-on a work weekday-what??! I love it and happy this place is here and thriving. There has been some turnover in this location since I've lived in Charlotte and it looks like this one will stay around for awhile.  I've heard fabulous things about all of the food---especially the chicken and flounder. You can choose a meat and choose three sides to go with it -most for under $10 which is a fantastic deal given the amount of food you could get. Our server was sweet, talkative and full of suggestions. She told us the meatloaf sold out each day so if we wanted to order it make sure we get there early. The special yesterday was Chicken Fried Chicken, which the other seven people in my group ordered. I was going to go with that but remembered reading Demetria M's review of the flounder. I decided to be a loner and order that along with collards, slaw and mac n cheese. If I'm eating comfort food, I'm going all out. Noshed on some biscuits before our meal came out (which seemed like it took 5 mins) and I am not a huge cornbread person but the others in my group said it was out of this world. The flounder was light, buttery and flaky and the tartar sauce was phenomenal!!! I think it was the best I've ever had and reminded me of a chunky aioli sauce rather than a traditional tartar. The mac n cheese, slaw and collards? Gone within five minutes. Everyone in my group received a membership to the clean plate club yesterday and I left without feeling the need to put on my fat pants. I cannot wait to visit again and will be saving room for their desserts--they all sound delicious.

photos.caption: Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States. Flounder w. slaw, mac n cheese and collards.

By_bzlQfmtsvQE08bGTeXw.text: We ate here about a month ago.  The fact that I can't remember the details doesn't speak so highly, but I do recall that it was good, if not exceptional.  Very solid comfort-food offerings, that mostly seemed to be at the appropriate price point for what's given.    I do remember that the first biscuits sent out were room temperature and seemed stale, but the waitress saw I had only picked at mine, and brought more out - this time from a fresh, hot batch.  Much better.   I had Meat & 3: pot roast, butternut squash, collards and mashed potatoes. The potatoes were listed with gravy on the menu, but only came out with a dish of broth/au jus on the side. I wasn't sure if that was supposed to be the "gravy", or if that was for the pot roast and they just forgot the potato gravy all together? Anyway, it was decent and filling, and would have had leftovers if I'd cared to take them home.  Nothing too special though.  Pot roast was fork-tender though, I'll give it that.  Fiance ordered...some kind of fried fish, with tomato jam on a bed of cheesy grits.  His dish was definitely of a higher caliber than mine, more upscale, both in presentation and in flavor experience, but you could have told that in advance based on the menu descriptions and prices of our respective dishes.  This was our first visit, spurred on by an about-to-expire online coupon we'd purchased.  Overall the experience was fine, but we had a long wait before being seated, and the jazz duo/trio (?), which we were seated near, was a bit too loud to be able to converse and hear each other.  King's Kitchen was fine for one evening's eating adventure, but there are other restaurants in Charlotte that we have had consistently better experiences at, so this one is unlikely to enter our repertoire for future revisits.

photos.caption: Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States. Pot roast, squash, collards, mashed potatoes; cornbread/biscuits; fried fish, tomato jam, cheesegrits

rVuUJ083dUBdyjAjRg9bFQ.text: Made a reservation for Thursday at 6:30 so we were able to walk right in. Two of us tried their Peach Sangria. They weren't horrible but they were watered down and a little sugar heavy. I ordered the catfish and my husband has the burger. He (and I) loved his burger. My catfish was a little salty but full disclosure I have a very low tolerance for salt. Not a bad restaurant and I love their mission!

photos.caption: Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States
Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States
Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States

THrUYx_UuyLLMzbr7FjObg.text: Jim Noble is one of the area's best restaurateurs, and King's Kitchen is a solid entry into his stable of eateries. Today was my second trip here, and as I usually bring my lunch I occasionally forget lunch in uptown Charlotte can set you back about twenty bucks. You'd think I got ripped off for spending that much on a BLT.   You'd be wrong.   Firstly, King's Kitchen is non-profit and helps those trying to get back on their feet by giving them a good, steady job. That alone is worth a higher price tag.  From a strictly selfish perspective, however, let's talk about the sandwich, a 3.5" high pile of heirloom tomato slices, baby field greens, thick slices of perfectly crisp bacon and Duke's mayo (because we are civilized southerners) between two slices of delicious toasted artisan bread.   I love tomato sandwiches but am persnickety as heck about my tomatoes. These heirlooms were perfect. I already want another one of these babies for dinner.   If the sandwich weren't enough, I also tried the mac and cheese, my favorite comfort food.  Shazam. Best I have had in the city. And the collards and butter beans my companions had looked delicious too.   Give King's Kitchen a try when you're hungry uptown. Not only will you be giving people a helping hand, you will also enjoy a darned good meal. This place is a Noble effort indeed.

savRnYVStaBsQV7tqawDaw.text: We came here based on solid Yelp reviews and we were not disappointed. We sat on the patio and just enjoyed the food and lovely atmosphere.  I ordered the scallops and bacon.   My entree was the best thing I've ever eaten (BOLD, yet True). The service was great.  I would highly recommend this place for a great night out with friends or a date night.

photos.caption: Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States

xEXQE2mt7C_Z4rJsesZs0w.text: This is one place we will definitely return to! I ordered the tri-tip steak, my coworkers got the burger and the shrimp and grits. All dishes were plated beautifully! Our server was able to recommend a great IPA for me and knew how to speak about the drafts! It was 630 on a weekday and it was bustling. Love that our meal helps a great cause! If you are in Charlotte... Definitely Go!

photos.caption: Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States. Tri tip steak cooked to medium rare, mushrooms sautéed in real butter and collards that would make my Granny proud!

2vkUzap8H4y2dhIanOpczA.text: Great lunch- pear, goat cheese, pecan gems salad with superb coffee & service.  A ministry that welcomes & trains homeless/formerly homeless neighbors.  Really good food.

photos.caption: Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States

yu46KaqcZmtcHZS2pR_W8A.text: They gave the best fried chicken hands down and all their sides are delicious. I wish they didn't have the sweet potato fritters seasonally.

kxz9isA4XpSWXW5Pf2Dgcw.text: This is my regular stop every time I'm in town for busy. Fast, efficient, friendly and the food a alright. On top of all that, it's a non-profit that helps the poor in the neighbors. Just for that I will give 5 stars (not my usual).

GdEx0vx8Jiznw5mV0MTcWw.text: We went to King's at 6:30 on Saturday.  We were surprised at the poor food quality.  The only dishes that were good were the fried oysters and the green beans.  The crab cake appetizer was barely warm and completely tasteless with a strange lumpy sauce.  The cornbread was bitter and dry.  The greens were unpleasant with a bad aftertaste.  The potatoes were more runny than the gravy.  But the worst thing was the fried chicken which came out barely warm and completely dry. I had to drink a few swallows of water to even get my first bite down.    It is so hard to find decent fried chicken in Charlotte and this version definitely goes on the scrap heap.  Disappointing!

cDqjkn47WEGA_9vPlc7PDg.text: Butter and salt galore! If you like everything to taste like butter and salt, come here, come here, come here.   We ordered a bunch of appetizers and I tried two different white wines. The local Riesling was better than the expensive French blend recommended by the server and was also the only local white on the menu--surprising for a place that emphasizes using local. The cheese plate was decent but the cheeses didn't have a lot of diversity to them and there wasn't enough bread for the amount of cheese. The fried oysters tasted like butter and salt so I loved it (and skipped the mayonnaise with the fancy caper remoulade title that was definitely mostly just mayonnaise) but the sweet potato fritters also tasted like salt and butter which was very disappointing since they smelled like delicious cinnamon. Those little balls came with a fabulous sweet butter that I even got extra to go. The Shishido peppers were nothing special, also tasting like butter and salt without a hint of any of the things it was supposed to taste like such as lime.   We each liked our entrees and didn't like the other's entree. I had the duck confit porridge and love rice and leeks so that made my meal, although the butter and salt flavors were still unnecessarily strong. I took one bite of the cornbread and decided it also needed to be slathered in the sweet butter from the sweet potato fritters--a bit of honey would have been preferred option. Partner had the pot roast with the lima and black eyed beans. I found the piece of meat to be 1/3 fat rather than meat and wasn't a fan, but he liked the flavor, the beans, and the biscuit. Surprise: we both thought the dish could use less butter and salt flavor... His mac and cheese was great, though.   I did the corn something dessert but when it came out it was just generic vanilla sherbet balls with three tiny pieces of dehydrated corn. Hmmm.  The bill was upwards of $100 for two people and I think the only leftovers were two fritters and my cornbread. Given that we were made to sweat out on the porch where people walked by smoking and cars honking and we could clearly see open tables inside all night, I'm not considering this a good value fine dining experience. But it wasn't a disaster, either. Just... singularly focused on butter and salt.

photos.caption: Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States. Bill for two just a bit over $100--fine except we were on the horrible porch and could see the empty tables inside all meal long!
Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States. These sweet potato fritters smelled great, with this heavenly cinnamon wafting into your nostrils after you bite--but no actual taste...
Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States. Generic cheese plate with little flavor and even less bread! Apple cider pickled onions always a perk, though.

bhASgDdgd_ILUSbrudtSPA.text: Excellent food!  We had a group of 8 (4 kids), and everyone loved their meal.  For a Saturday night, the place wasn't busy.  We had a reservation and because of our group's size we got the private room.  Highly recommend.

hcAZq9PgjCskP-OQnX1sbg.text: We've been here a few times and haven't been disappointed yet. The staff is friendly and welcoming and the food is good southern homestyle cooking. As an added bonus, the restaurant is not for profit and serves locally sourced foods.

SMW7lMfUrfj15ctF3fZvNg.text: We've been reading about this place for a while... one of our party lives in Charlotte , the other two of us are out of towners, and we wanted to try "southern style".  We went for lunch, on a beautiful day, and were able to sit outside.  Having read the "share"idea on the menu, and hearing that the portions are rather large, we ordered one fried chicken dinner for the three of us!  We ordered our 3 sides, mmm (especially liked the greens) and by mistake the waiter brought us a Mac and cheese that we hadn't asked for.  So we had 4 sides, and ordered an extra biscuit.  That was enough for us!!  Very good food, good value for money, and though it is not evident, a small contribution to a good cause..   calm atmosphere sitting on the patio.  Servers were all very friendly.... dessert - banana pudding - seemed rather pricey, and none of us were too excited about the marshmallow topping.. (sometimes it's all about what you're used to).  This restaurant is uptown, so either come by rail, or expect some parking difficulties during the day.

GoYhBW_8VV6t6ESmedqy0g.text: Fastest service I've ever received from any restaurant in Uptown. Friendly service from start to finish. You can't go wrong with fried chicken & mashed potatoes. The side biscuits are the perfect size to get a taste of their deliciousness but not fill up too much to enjoy your meal and save room for dessert. I was recommended by a friend to try the banana pudding. I don't know what other desserts they have without going to look at the menu, but it doesn't matter - this banana pudding is amazing! It's more of a custard than a typical pudding I've had in the past, and the toasted marshmallow topping completes the entire meal.   With the quick and friendly service from all the staff and the great food, I will make King's Kitchen a weekly visit!

UnUMzI5XJLz2iW334GRq-w.text: Went here tonight with a few coworkers on a whim. We were walking to another restaurant and were drawn in by the decor and recipes painted on the outside. We were not disappointed! Everything was wonderful, from the ambiance to the service and the food. We tried many things on the menu and each was delicious. I love the mission of this restaurant and I'm so glad we stopped in. Highly recommend!!

1-NHe8xOU8lB4qYAX7_vfg.text: Not only is the mission behind this place amazing the food is nothing short of that either. The food is absolutely amazing, I can't rave it enough!

pqoktWWobG9yuajWKYeuKg.text: This restaurant is awesome!  Beautiful interior with lovely staff.  The menu is wonderfully prepared with a select variety of pure bliss!  I dine out alone when I travel so I look for places that are a bit homey and I felt very welcomed upon entering.  The lighting is just right, clean and the music are old hits that are enjoyable. I ordered the pot roast which was very tender and not smothered in a ton of sauce.  The mashed potatoes are perfect. Then finished off with coffee and and a slice of apple pie.  Very delicious not too sweet, fresh and the coffee was better than the chain coffee shops. You would enjoy this place it's elevated southern food to a elegant level.

izwVOKhofiWL6l9wLgzGvA.text: Harold our server was excellent.  Informative, efficient and unobtrusive.  The food was also excellent.    The following all delicious: Jalapeno hushpuppies Catfish Butter Beans Salmon Apple Cabbage Mashed Potatoes and Gravy Pan-fried chicken Mac & Cheese Frittes Coconut Cake Chess Cake  The following were not good: ....  One of the best restaurant experiences we have ever had and clearly the best Southern dining we have experienced

0Y-d-tLHf7uJenUcP5IGXQ.text: Two entrees and an appetizer. The duck entree was tasty a bit disappointing that they were out of duck egg. The shrimp and grits were solid but not the best we've had. The appetizer sweet potato fritters were tasty. The dessert chocolate mousse was a little too sweet and didn't taste fresh.  So, given the fairly high price point, it's not quite a four star experiene.

1yjHiDGHxiiftBAeDV-TWA.text: I planned a business dinner for out team in the Charlotte area and chose The King's Kitchen because of the great reviews and their mission to feed the hungry in the community.  Because of the size of our group - they required that we preset our menu and adjust the time of our event so our experience would be optimal.    When we walked in, the expansive bar area was just starting to fill up with dinner patrons.  They serve only beer and wine but the menus for both were varied and extensive enough to please everyone.    Our server was friendly and helpful - it took awhile to get things rolling, like our drink and app order, but once we did, the pace was ok.    The menu options included chicken, pot roast, vegetarian risotto and salmon.  I don't believe anyone ordered the risotto and I only heard feedback about the salmon (which was dry for a few that ordered it).  I had the pot roast which was a nice sized portion but was slightly chewy.  Everyone who had the fried chicken seemed to be pleased with their choice.  The sides were the highlight of the evening - we chose butter beans, mac 'n cheese and green beans.  The mac 'n cheese was slightly under seasoned for my taste but the pasta was cooked to perfection and the cheese was creamy in the center and appropriately crusty on the top.  I thought the butter beans were amazing and the green beans while a bit overcooked, were full of flavor.   We tried a few of the desserts - banana pudding and angel food cake to name a few.  All were tasty and came in generous portions.    Overall, everyone enjoyed the meal and the service.  I wouldn't hesitate to recommend The King's Kitchen but I'd probably try another dining spot in the Uptown area before I'd venture back.

TOoffVefWKXKb9WBPOX3eQ.text: Waitstaff is great, small menu but True southern soul food! Wine & local beer. Lots of side options and the chicken and pot roast comes with 3 sides! Plus cornbread or biscuit. And it's a non profit that helps feed the hungry in the community so can't beat that

NZwhEU1dq20Xtx6V7xgW5w.text: Awesome Southern cooking! The concept of this restaurant is so cool. Check the website for deets! But the food is cooked to perfection and service was great. The bathroom needs a bit of work and the Dessert/pastry display could be loved, but my meal was top notch. Biscuits are big and fluffy and the fried chicken doesn't disappoint.

gYMjNMmvQMmRGj7LcfnAUg.text: The food was great! It was a little pricey but the quality was good.   Our server was a little strange but very helpful and knew the menu.   For a first timer, King's Kitchen did not disappoint!

HxYKKn4zhmlcrC-U9LB9ZA.text: Went here last night for the first time.  The outdoor patio is a great spot with plenty of tables.   The food is known for its southern roots and they were sold out of the fried chicken which was disappointing.   I ended up with the shrimp and grits that were very good.  Overall a good spot if you want down home southern cooking.

zrdEyvqzxHfg4GdK68RnYQ.text: Allow me to save you from wasting a meal at this place.  Our first clue should have been it wasn't crowded.  The restaurant is not fancy, almost a cafeteria feel.  Only serve beer and wine.  My food was so over salted, I still taste salt nearly 3 hours later.  Overpriced for what you get, at least the scallops - you get four.  Not enough on the dish for a meal.  Another person in our party had the collard greens and said they were not good at all. Server was cordial, nothing special.  Really annoyed that we came here.  DON'T DO IT.  There's plenty of good restaurants.  How this place has a high star rating is beyond belief.

JjXzpHQo_fIElo7w8Sekqg.text: Absolutely DELICIOUS! I was only in town for two days, and I went here for dinner. I had the warm cabbage salad, fried oysters, and brownie cheesecake, which was all amazing - so good I decided to go back for lunch the next day! I had the friend chicken sandwich (SO tasty), black eyed peas (fine, but nothing exciting), cornbread (good), and the sorbet for dessert, which was tasty!   The mission behind the restaurant is really awesome, and I was glad to support them in their work.

i6Rl5G1fGWtVFHj0DoDXeg.text: I love the idea behind this restaurant, but was disappointed by the experience. Some of the food had a chemical taste and the waitstaff didn't seem to notice I barely ate any of it. I had to ask several times for an extra plate and hot sauce which I never got. Don't think I'll be back.

8Jc6dgKkqv64y_4Q5rxOZw.text: The Anson Mills grits were the creamiest, gooiest, yummiest grits I've ever eaten.  Each bite was adorned with a shrimp and sliver of surryano country ham.  When the chef told me the grist were cheese-free, I looked at him like he was lying!  I'm still in a state of shock!  I'm not a big fan of their fried chicken or their cornbread, but I love the restaurant's mission.

9MDznt7zu0wHXy8O6kXkXw.text: The meal was excellent. I ordered the beet salad as an appetizer and the sea scallops with succotash for the entree. Both were very flavorful. As dessert, I ordered the peanut butter cheesecake. Although it was good, it was unexpected. It didn't taste much like peanut butter. There was just a small spoonful of peanut butter in the center.   The meal came out fast, which was refreshing. The only down side that we all joint was the portion sizes. The deserts in particular are small. Not really shareable.

QypOPwBsBP_pzT4w7vujNA.text: Outstanding food and even better story & mission. Scallops were delicious.  Fried chicken looked outstanding. The servings were large, service was top-notch.

xRDIDdVYAVB0n6Qqhmfr4A.text: I loved the food here.  I also think it's awesome that they use the money they take in to help people.  The shrimp and grits were great.

NRHHh3x7zgIEsfS1ydmhow.text: Nice place very nice place with great food... the service is excellent ....I'm definitely going back to this place... try the shrimp and grits very great taste... I love it

FAee6ZGYBQybkKznI0RyVA.text: I'm visiting Charlotte for the week and someone suggested this place to me. I was pleasantly surprised!   We started with the sweet potato fritters, I don't usually like sweet potatoes but these were delicious. Then I ordered the fried chicken with Mac and cheese, cabbage, an creamy potatoes. Every single thing was delicious! I ended up ordering an extra side of Mac and cheese. Having the biscuit on the side was the perfect way to end the meal. I would definitely return!

n_Cf0n49LYlERDERQFB8yw.text: Our experience at King's Kitchen was FANTASTIC. It instantly became a favorite place for us. The service was excellent, the food was delicious- served timely, hot and orders were spot on, and the atmosphere was uplifting. I cannot say enough good things at King's Kitchen!

n7waGii2gIEa4vVK5-qbDg.text: I love this place. I love the mission of this restaurant and the quality of the food. A great place for lunch during the work week and a nice dinner  before going to the symphony !... Go you will not be disappointed.

SA5AOod4ZiFqyPTriH05IA.text: Excellent service, very personable. Some entrees can be pricey, but the food is out of this world. Also, the mission of the restaurant is to serve a higher purpose. Would recommend!

tpNkkoUyXwsr5mOF1M1Ksg.text: I have lived about two blocks away from this place for over a year now and for some reason we haven't found the time to stop by King's for dinner.  Well, we finally did and I am so glad that we did!!    We started out with the fried oysters as our app and they were... Kick A$$!!! (see pic).  They were huge with the perfect amount of crispiness and textured seafood gooey'ness on the inside.  They were accompanied by delicious cocktail sauce and a second balsamic vinegar dressing thing.. Never had that type of dipping sauce for oysters before but it sure worked!  I then moved on to the Fried Catfish and WOW!  It was excellent.  The perfect amount of herbs and spices in the batter mix complimented the an ideal flaky delicious fish.  I was blown away with the taste.  Not to mention, they gave us three side options for the entree.  I went with the collard greens, fried mac n' cheese, and the mashed potatoes.  I would highly suggest you do the same.  You cant go wrong with some collard greens.    My only issue would have to be the fact that they NAILED this dinner perfectly.  Now, I am going to go back and have to order the same thing and not try anything new.  I know, crazy frustrating, right?    Enjoy!!  -Ian M.

photos.caption: Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States. Fried Oysters
Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States. Fried catfish

yQN9Mm5z6oev9P7pWvpmyQ.text: The staff was great, and I love the mission of this restaurant. But I'm rating the food experience and unfortunately I must have caught the restaurant on a bad night. The fried chicken was tough, and the mac & cheese was extremely salty. The collard greens were great, though. We were treating an of state guest to dinner, and we chose to come here. We were unfortunately disappointed in the meal, not what you want to happen with an out of state guest. I may give it another try someday, but not with a guest.

QIaHptOWykhpMQQWYCdvfg.text: I'm pretty sold on King's Kitchen. Their fried catfish in cheesy grits was truly excellent, and though their fried chicken is more famous, the catfish is truly the way to go.  The sides are all top notch also and their cornbread is absurdly buttery.  I feel like I should have more to say for a 5 star review but I don't.   Protip - go for lunch, it's the same food but much cheaper.

WN_r8GJjxdqZfwOT4Su7MA.text: We started our meal with Sweet Potato Fritters and Hoppin John.  The fritters were served with honey as a dipping sauce and belonged on the dessert menu.  The Hoppin John was OK. However. for an entree I had the bone-in pork chop and it was fantastic!  SO incredibly juicy and flavorful.  I was a little surprised to see that of the 3 out of 4 people at my table that all ordered that, they were all a different size.  By quite a bit.  I was a little ticked that mine was the smallest by almost half of the gentleman's to my right.  I may be a lady, but I can eat and I am being charged the same.  They need to talk with their butcher or sell it market price by the ounce.

tftmV3iVBTSxq8VVfAalVw.text: Sigh. I REALLY wanted to like this place. I've been wanting to try it for months, ever since I've been planning a trip to Charlotte for my mother and searching for the perfect dinner spot to meet her tastes. We arrived on a Friday evening around 5 and were promptly seated by a very courteous host. My mother ordered a vegetable plate (her standard order anywhere) and I ordered the white meat pan-fried chicken meal with green beans, macaroni and cheese, and potato salad, with cornbread as my bread option. It literally took less than five minutes to get our meals out, which was the first clue that disappointment was soon to follow. Five minutes is fine if you're just scooping vegetables onto a plate, but that short turnaround time told me my chicken was not going to be freshly cooked. And I was correct. The sides I ordered were great, but the chicken was so dry I had to take each bite with a sip of water. If I'm paying $15 for a chicken plate, it should not be so dry that I fear death by choking. Did I get the leftovers from lunch that had been dehydrating under the salamander all afternoon? Did patrons after me get fresh chicken, or is it always dry like this? I may never know, because the chances of me returning here are slim when Charlotte has so many great places to eat.

z25CUDmQxa2JvRqvInxMlg.text: Noble idea that fails at execution. Would have been one star for food alone, but bumped to two because they aspire to more.  Tried it for lunch today and am impressed with its mission of feeding the flock. But. (!)  It's a restaurant, so it's job should first be feeding its patrons. That where it totally fails. Cornbread was nasty and dry. Suitable as bird feed, but not for people. Meatloaf was dry and unpleasant too. Sides were below average.   Much better meal choice is to walk to Gus's and then donate $5 to your favorite charity.

OQCmBkJJKCk1cko4gwk6RQ.text: True taste of southern. Pimiento cheese and shrimp and grits were on point. Definitely must visit when in Charlotte!

rkIGw-BDpXm6QO7Icd49og.text: Kings Kitchen is conveniently located across from the Marriott hotel and has naturally become one of my regular dinner spots. It serves up southern cuisine with a bit of a twist, and all of the food is great quality. I definitely recommend eating in rather than grabbing takeout, but both are good options. I recommend trying the fried chicken and the salmon with a side of the creamed corn.

zGiALfByf9O67SGaqcU_hQ.text: I was in town at a conference and looking for some good Southern comfort food. As usual, Yelp came through.  My two friends and I split two meat and three plates with collard greens, green beans, butter beans, mashed potatoes and gravy, and mac and cheese, an appetizer of fried oysters, a side of carmelized beets, and grilled cornbread. Everything was good, but the fried oysters and green beans were great! I also enjoyed a tasty IPA and banana pudding with toasted marshmallow topping for dessert. Yummy! Luckily, the restaurant was almost a mile from the hotel, so we had some time to walk off some of this great meal.  And best of all, this restaurant donates its profits to help the City's homeless and hungry. As they say on the menu, "Eat chicken and feed somebody." Who could ask for more?

qxGdnpVnEZhMxLDcZ_V70g.text: This little gem in Charlotte serves delicious food and a great message to boot.  (Check out the origin on-line). I always believe in promoting good ideas that not only fill your tummy but your heart as well.  We ordered a variety of items all of which were amazing   The favorites included the gumbo (spicy but not mouth on fire), salmon served with greens, black eyed peas, amazeballs Mac and cheese (sorry this is the only word to describe it), followed by banana pudding complete with a meringue topping.  The company was great of course and the service was attentive without over doing it. Happy to say if I find myself in Charlotte again I will be visiting! If you haven't tried out this place you are missing out.

UwNZtXwrcgDbHeOszK5V9g.text: Amazing. This place was delicious. And I'm not a fan of fried chicken and theirs was the best!!! Not too much breading and it was so juicy and delicious. Can't wait to go back.

iH2UOQoUI1hYIJFPb46RBg.text: Excellent food. Excellent service. Shrimp & grits are spicey but delicious! My son's fried chicken was very good. He chose cream corn (sweet & delicious), green beans (great flavor) & mac-n-chees. I don't even like mac-n-cheese & I finished what my son didn't eat because it was that good! My wife ordered duck & it was very tender. The portions are sized perfectly to give you room for dessert. The bread pudding was the best I've EVER had (and enough to share)!

BZJ71_ptGwOyruGsUNK5ug.text: Found this place on Yelp and it was walking distance from the hotel(plus) I saw the reviews on the shrimp and grits however I don't eat pork and they mix the ham in with the grits so some of my options were a no go. Some veggies had pork in it as well. I do appreciate the waiter informing me about the veggies when I let them know I do not eat pork. I got the flounder with the Mac and cheese and my friend got the chicken plate with green beans(pork in it) and mushrooms.  My meal was pretty good, the Mac and cheese was exceptionally good which is always a hit and miss.(seasoned well). My flounder was breaded and pretty good, cannot complain.  My friend first received a burned chicken breast but was quickly and happily changed for another piece. I actually tried a piece of the chicken and it was very good. I'm a fan of mushrooms but they were very salty(for my friends liking).  I also had a biscuit and my friend had the cornbread, both were good.  For dessert my friend got the coconut cake, even though they expected a bigger piece it was good. Soft and moist. Would I come back to the Kings kitchen yes...

_QdiGZQJZ-uYKgiEItLAbA.text: Great service and great food  real sweet tea   We had meatloaf.  It had a mustard sauce  it was wonderful .  Highly recommend the restaurant.  Great cause and incredible food

cXnj68Y-6X5R88mh3t9L_w.text: Cool place to come for lunch if you have a bit of time.    The food was prepared very well and wasn't expensive.  Came here for a work lunch thing and it took a long time to get the food.  Service was nice.    dmo out

kfWYeQ4mUNRJkAwkqcFMqw.text: It's good, service is suspiciously fast, but I enjoyed the fried chicken, mushrooms, black eyed peas, and collard greens. The corn bread was a disappointment, I wish I had gotten the biscuit. Overall, a good place to go and have a home cooked meal.

2OcwNwFL37RwbPabdstlXQ.text: How can you not give a restaurant that serves amazing food and also gives all of their proceeds back to the community? Service was fantastic and the food was even better. Everything on the menu was reasonably priced. We will return!

photos.caption: Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States. The bread pudding is amazing. It takes 25 minutes to prepare, so make sure you ask for it early. Ask for a second scoop of ice cream!

tAO6o_XK7fNfhWkAF0ejsQ.text: The kale salad was phenomenal. We also had the fried chicken which was pretty good, mac and cheese which was amazing, and green beans.  I was not a fan of the green beans as they have a large hunk of ham and and tasted extremely smoky. The staff was really nice and really helpful.

GyyU7cKbDTUSAaxgv6Wszw.text: I really love the philanthropic concept of King's Kitchen; however, the food and service were both just average at best during my visit. We started with an appetizer of sweet potato fritters, and to be blunt- they were awful. They were way too salty and had way too much ginger and cloves; did not taste like sweet potatoes at all. If you like honey, they became edible by dipping them in the sweet honey sauce, but I would still definitely avoid them. For my entree, I ordered the pot roast meat and three with mac & cheese, collard greens, green beans, and a biscuit. The pot roast was exceptional - so tender and flavorful; you didn't even need a knife to eat it. The mac and cheese was pretty solid as well. It was baked custard style which I like but wasn't that cheesy. The collard greens and green beans were okay but nothing special. The biscuit was dry and crumbly but according to our server is a lot better than the cornbread. My girlfriend ordered the pork chop, but unfortunately it came out overcooked and a bit burnt on the one side. It was certainly edible, but not something you'd want to pay $25 for. Her side of "fondant sweet potatoes" was 5 slices of very thin sweet potato baked and with little seasoning or flavor. That leads me to my biggest disappointment- the portion size. My girlfriend isn't a big eater, but she was still hungry after her small pork chop and even smaller side dish. When I think of a classic southern "meat and three", I'm thinking that I'm going to be absolutely stuffed full of food and/or have some to take home, but the portions were really small. All three sides were small portions, and the pot roast was maybe 4-5 ounces of meat. Our server was a friendly guy, and I respect that they help the homeless recover by offering them jobs, but he did not check on us much at all once our food hit the table, and he seemed very confused every time we ordered, although luckily everything was correct. He also spoke very quietly so it was almost impossible for us to understand what the specials were or what he asked us that wasn't obvious.  I'm disappointed that I didn't love King's Kitchen since it is such an awesome concept but the food, service, and portion sizes were all letdowns for a $50+ dinner without drinks.

photos.caption: Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States. Pot Roast with Mac &amp; Cheese, Collards, Green Beans, Biscuit
Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States. Sweet Potato Fritters
Photo of The King's Kitchen - Charlotte, NC, United States. Pork Chop with Sweet Potato Fondant

Jxjg3rSA3222smumHlfc5A.text: I have the deepest respect for The King's Kitchen. As a pastor and missionary, I've been to many other mission-oriented restaurants, but I've never seen it done with such class.    The whole place is ran with excellence, and it shows. I consider myself a connoisseur of authentic southern soul food, and they nailed it.  If I HAD to say SOMETHING negative, I guess it would be that home cooked fried chicken made in a skillet is better than restaurant fried chicken from a deep fryer, but that's about the worst I could say. And kudos on serving deviled eggs!

kemxoEeyCGz_95Cv7SRQ5w.text: Went there for lunch by seeing some good reviews and it was a total disaster. I ordered fried catfish which came with 3 sides. None of it tasted good. The presentation and the gigantic quantity spoke for the quality and taste itself. The fish had no taste and was soaked in oil, the potato salad itself was not cooked properly, the beans was just canned beans and the collard greens was sweet and overlooked with water dripping. Also don't ignore the flies that's all around if you decide to sit in the patio.

CnBPJsKm5mtT73L8AwN7MQ.text: Just passing through Charlotte and decided to try this gem for lunch. Love the mission of the restaurant! Decor is nice. Service was good. Family ordered oyster pizza boy- DELISH! Tomato bisque- yummy! Chicken tenders- Mmmm! Everything tastes very fresh.

oXXkiUPr5ulSmXhB8Kw7WA.text: Hands down, one of the worst place I have been to... I have never been so disappointed. Service was horrible. Food was cold and mediocre. Was expecting a lot more.
